issue.title: ArgumentCaptor and ArgumentMatcher can't be mixed in varargs

milestone.title: 2.x
milestone.description: Changes tentatively planned in 2.x versions of Mockito

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

body:
We are aware of that issue, the design of this tool is to rely on the method signature. Not to capture an argument of a certain type.

This tool will be redesigned for Mockito 2.1. It would be nice if it could allow developers to express an arg capture depending on conditions or to capture everything passing by.
@ChristianSchwarz, guys any ideas how to improve it?

@ChristianSchwarz Hi,
This seems to be related to #358. WDYT?

@terebesirobert 

> This seems to be related to #358. WDYT?

Absolutly, I splitted #358 cause it included two toppics:
1. adding a new captor API `captureIf( )`,still ticket #358
2. type safe capture, this ticket

I think your PR #358 can be used to fix this issue. Since the the new API captureIf(..) is not approved by the mockito-core-team I think it should be excluded for this issue. Maybe you can create a branch of your solution and send a new PR to fix this issue.

issue.title: ArgumentCaptor: NPE when an null array is passed to a varargs method

milestone.title: 2.x
milestone.description: Changes tentatively planned in 2.x versions of Mockito

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
A NullPointerException is thrown if an null array is passed to a varargs method.

```
@Test
public void shouldCaptureVarArgs_nullArrayArg() {
        String[] argArray = null;
        mock.varargs(argArray);

        verify(mock).varargs(captor.capture()); //<- Kaboom NPE
}
```

Since an vararg is simply an array the ArgumentCaptor should reject it silently. This relates to #565.

```
java.lang.NullPointerException
    at java.lang.reflect.Array.getLength(Native Method)
    at org.mockito.internal.invocation.InvocationMatcher.captureVarargsPart(InvocationMatcher.java:142)
    at org.mockito.internal.invocation.InvocationMatcher.captureArgumentsFrom(InvocationMatcher.java:122)
    at org.mockito.internal.invocation.InvocationMarker.markVerified(InvocationMarker.java:24)
    at org.mockito.internal.invocation.InvocationMarker.markVerified(InvocationMarker.java:18)
    at org.mockito.internal.verification.checkers.NumberOfInvocationsChecker.check(NumberOfInvocationsChecker.java:43)
    at org.mockito.internal.verification.Times.verify(Times.java:40)
    at org.mockito.internal.verification.MockAwareVerificationMode.verify(MockAwareVerificationMode.java:21)
    at org.mockito.internal.handler.MockHandlerImpl.handle(MockHandlerImpl.java:73)
    at org.mockito.internal.handler.NullResultGuardian.handle(NullResultGuardian.java:32)
    at org.mockito.internal.handler.InvocationNotifierHandler.handle(InvocationNotifierHandler.java:37)
    at org.mockito.internal.creation.bytebuddy.MockMethodInterceptor.doIntercept(MockMethodInterceptor.java:36)
    at org.mockito.internal.creation.bytebuddy.MockMethodInterceptor.access$0(MockMethodInterceptor.java:32)
    at org.mockito.internal.creation.bytebuddy.MockMethodInterceptor$DispatcherDefaultingToRealMethod.interceptAbstract(MockMethodInterceptor.java:113)
    at org.mockitousage.IMethods$MockitoMock$81506210.varargs(Unknown Source)
    at org.mockitousage.matchers.VarargsTest.shouldCaptureVarArgs_nullArrayArg(VarargsTest.java:182)
```

issue.title: Support lambda when syntax

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
It would be awesome to support a syntax like this:

``` java
Mockito.when(mock::method).isInvokedWith(foo,bar).thenAnswer((foo, bar) -> 5);
```

The benefits: true type safety. Currently we have an interim solution which helps a lot with Java 8, but it still [relies on casting](https://github.com/mockito/mockito/blob/master/src/main/java/org/mockito/internal/stubbing/answers/AnswerFunctionalInterfaces.java#L39).
Also the `when` syntax can be confusing compared to the `verify` syntax, since verify actually has the method call on the return value of `verify()` whereas `when` wants the method call inside its function argument.

This reads a lot more fluent imo and given the compiler warnings and similarity to `verify` could greatly benefit new users.

The biggest issue with this syntax is probably: how do we track the lambda reference? I have tried to come up with a proof of concept, but since `mock::method` just returns a `Function` without any points to what mock it was actually referring too, I could not extract the actual mock we should stub for. Maybe we can do some Bytecode magic there?

body: What is the status of this (or #358)?

Type-safety is still something I am investigating, targeting Mockito 3. It seems that fixing it without strong typing, e.g. dynamically checking the generics, is very hacky and error-prone. It would be nice to have a solution where the compiler can catch these issues and make sure the verification is working, rather than on run-time failing.

issue.title: Cannot verify varargs parameter as an array

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.title: Investigation public API Mockito

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
This ticket tries to summarize which features are similar in our public API. The intention is to give an overview of which code we have to maintain, as well as trying to identify inconsistencies and confusion between various API's

# Stubbing
There are 9 ways to stub a method:

```java
when(mock.foo()).thenReturn('Bar');
doReturn('Bar').when(mock).foo();

when(mock.foo()).thenThrow(MockException.class);
when(mock.foo()).thenThrow(new MockException());
doThrow(MockException.class).when(mock).foo();
doThrow(new MockException()).when(mock).foo();

doNothing().when(mock).foo();

when(mock.foo()).thenAnswer(new Answer() {...});
doAnswer(new Answer() {...}).when(mock).foo();
```

And there are 2 ways to call the real method:

```java
when(mock.foo()).thenCallRealMethod();
doCallRealMethod().when(mock).foo();
```

The existence of 2+ ways to achieve the same thing, is because of the way stubs are handled.
In general, `when(mock.foo())` is the preferred way to stub.
However, sometimes we already stubbed this method (#1237), we want to stub it but it is a spy (#500), the method is a consumer (returns `void`).
For all these cases, the different stubbing method has to be used (e.g. the `doXYZ().when(mock).foo()`).
New users get confused by this difference and can confuse the 2 API's quite easily.

We also completely mirror our full API in BDDMockito, because the name `when()` was changed to `given()`.

## Stubbing vs Verification

In contrast, verification always uses the pattern `verify(mock).foo()`.
This method is yet again a different syntax than the one used for stubbing.
Reason being: we don't want to prematurely invoke the method, because it would run the stub.
This stub could throw an exception, screwing up the test.

I still remember that when I was a first-time user of Mockito (~4 years ago), this difference in API thoroughly confused me.

# VerificationModes

## After and Timeout

There is a very subtle difference between the two API's, as described in #472.
Even to me, the difference is so subtle I would not know which one to use in which situation.
Rather, I would like to see an API based on real-world use-cases, presumably related to Futures and Observables.

## Multiple Modes

The API for VerificationModes is pretty brittle atm.
This is largely a result of [`VerificationWrapper`](https://github.com/mockito/mockito/blob/release/2.x/src/main/java/org/mockito/internal/verification/VerificationWrapper.java) which is tightly coupled to all of our implementations of `VerificationMode`.
Moreover, there is a different wrapper specifically for in-order matching, which is treated completely different.

As a user, it is hard to create custom `VerificationMode`, while still being able to use multiple modes at the same time.
See #339, #417 for examples of users wanting to add usage of a new mode.

# ArgumentMatchers

As noted in the JavaDoc of `ArgumentMatchers`:

> Matcher methods like anyObject(), eq() do not return matchers. Internally, they record a matcher on a stack and return a dummy value (usually null). This implementation is due to static type safety imposed by java compiler. The consequence is that you cannot use anyObject(), eq() methods outside of verified/stubbed method.

At the moment, we do internal verification of Mockito static state to detect this misuse.
For new users, this distinction is very subtle and generates quite some confusion.

## Auto-boxing

As noted in the JavaDoc of `ArgumentMatchers`:

> NullPointerException auto-unboxing caveat. In rare cases when matching primitive parameter types you *must* use relevant intThat(), floatThat(), etc. method. This way you will avoid NullPointerException during auto-unboxing. Due to how java works we don't really have a clean way of detecting this scenario and protecting the user from this problem. Hopefully, the javadoc describes the problem and solution well. If you have an idea how to fix the problem, let us know via the mailing list or the issue tracker.

Once again, this is a very subtle case that throws a NPE in "unexpected" ways.

## any{Map, Set, Collection, Iterable, ...}

There are a lot of methods that return classes with generics, to correctly compile with the method.
However, the generics are completely discarded on run-time (since we have no information).
The implementations thus do something like `new InstanceOf(Collection.class, "<any collection>")`.
Using the API gives users the impression we support generics, even though we don't.

## XYZThat()

We have a lot of `XYZThat()` methods that wrap custom matchers, but then return a default value.
Wrapper matchers like that seems unnecessary and would be nice if we could avoid that.

## eq()

These methods exist, as we need to call methods with the correct type.
The reason they have to be default values, is because we don't know whether we stubbed them or not (see section #Stubbing).

## Duplicate implementation

If I understand correctly, the following methods achieve the same (taken from `ArgumentMatchers` and `AdditionalMatchers`):

* `isA(Class)` and `any(Class)`
* `nullable(Class)` and `or(isNull(), any(Class))`
* `startsWith("foo")` and `matches("^foo")`
* `endsWith("foo")` and `matches("foo$")`
* `find("foo")` and `matches("foo")` and `contains("foo")`

There is also a large amount of implementations for `or()`, `and()` and `not()` as well as arithmetic matchers as `gt()`.

## Feature expansion and misuse

Even though we have a large amount of matchers, we still receive updates with additions for new APIs such as #1164.
Moreover, we have very hard-to-debug issues like #689 where we have to detect misuse of the API.
And we have issues like #1204 where types are failing verifications.

# ArgumentCaptor

Slightly related to `ArgumentMatcher`, we also support capturing arguments.
While useful, interaction resulted in debates about its API (#474), lack of type-safety (#565), inability to deal with varargs (#585) and integration with matchers (#358).

# (Additional-)Answers

There is duplication between `answer()` and `answerVoid()` as a result of how we handle consumers vs functions.
This is mainly an issue, because we can't do `when(mock.consumer())` as `void` is not allowed to be passed in.
Moreover, we have several (seemingly arbitrary) answers that implement functionality like `returnsFirstArg()`.
This is a direct result of our brittle API with `invocation` which makes handling answers quite cumbersome.

# Conclusion

All in all, I think 1. our public API surface is too large and 2. extensibility with custom matchers/answers/etc... is quite cumbersome.
My conclusion regarding API size, is largely related to lack of type-safety and annoyances with Java 5-6.
With lambdas in Java 8+, we should be able to tackle these problems in a lot nicer way.
This should open up a unified way to handle functions + consumers, remove the need for a lot of our custom matchers/answers and simply replace them with lambdas.
